sn47.10:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn47.10:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the nuns’ quarters, and sat down on the seat spread out.

sn47.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhuniyo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn47.10:1.2.eng: Then several nuns went up to Venerable Ānanda bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.10:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhante ānanda, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharantiyo uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānantī”ti.
sn47.10:2.1.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, several nuns meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They have realized a higher distinction than they had before.”

sn47.10:2.2.eng: “That’s how it is, sisters! That’s how it is, sisters!

sn47.10:2.3.pli: Yo hi koci, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
sn47.10:2.3.eng: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to

sn47.10:2.4.eng: realize a higher distinction than they had before.”

sn47.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tā bhikkhuniyo dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
sn47.10:3.1.eng: Then Ānanda educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired those nuns with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

sn47.10:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.10:3.2.eng: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn47.10:4.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃ.

sn47.10:4.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho, bhante, tā bhikkhuniyo maṃ etadavocuṃ:

sn47.10:4.3.pli: ‘idha, bhante ānanda, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharantiyo uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānantī’ti.

sn47.10:4.4.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, tā bhikkhuniyo etadavocaṃ:

sn47.10:4.6.pli: Yo hi koci, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānissatī’”ti.

sn47.10:5.1.eng: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!

sn47.10:5.2.pli: Yo hi koci, ānanda, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
sn47.10:5.2.eng: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to

sn47.10:5.3.eng: realize a higher distinction than they had before.

sn47.10:6.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.10:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.10:6.3.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato kāyārammaṇo vā uppajjati kāyasmiṃ pariḷāho, cetaso vā līnattaṃ, bahiddhā vā cittaṃ vikkhipati.
sn47.10:6.3.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, based on the body there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.

sn47.10:6.4.pli: Tenānanda, bhikkhunā kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahitabbaṃ.
sn47.10:6.4.eng: That mendicant should direct their mind towards an inspiring subject as a basis for meditation.

sn47.10:6.5.pli: Tassa kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
sn47.10:6.5.eng: As they do so, joy springs up.

sn47.10:6.7.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn47.10:6.8.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

sn47.10:6.9.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn47.10:6.11.pli: ‘yassa khvāhaṃ atthāya cittaṃ paṇidahiṃ, so me attho abhinipphanno.
sn47.10:6.11.eng: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.

sn47.10:6.13.pli: So paṭisaṃharati ceva na ca vitakketi na ca vicāreti.
sn47.10:6.13.eng: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.

sn47.10:6.14.eng: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’

sn47.10:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.10:7.3.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.10:7.3.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.10:7.4.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato dhammārammaṇo vā uppajjati kāyasmiṃ pariḷāho, cetaso vā līnattaṃ, bahiddhā vā cittaṃ vikkhipati.
sn47.10:7.4.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, based on principles there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.

sn47.10:7.5.pli: Tenānanda, bhikkhunā kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahitabbaṃ.
sn47.10:7.5.eng: That mendicant should direct their mind towards an inspiring subject as a basis for meditation.

sn47.10:7.6.pli: Tassa kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
sn47.10:7.6.eng: As they do so, joy springs up.

sn47.10:7.8.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn47.10:7.9.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

sn47.10:7.10.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn47.10:7.12.pli: ‘yassa khvāhaṃ atthāya cittaṃ paṇidahiṃ, so me attho abhinipphanno.
sn47.10:7.12.eng: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.

sn47.10:7.14.pli: So paṭisaṃharati ceva na ca vitakketi na ca vicāreti.
sn47.10:7.14.eng: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.

sn47.10:7.15.eng: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’

sn47.10:7.16.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, paṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti.
sn47.10:7.16.eng: That’s how there is directed development.

sn47.10:8.1.eng: And how is there undirected development?

sn47.10:8.2.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.2.eng: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

sn47.10:8.3.eng: And they understand: ‘Before and behind, it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

sn47.10:8.4.pli: Atha ca pana ‘kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.4.eng: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

sn47.10:8.5.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.5.eng: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

sn47.10:8.6.eng: And they understand: ‘Before and behind, it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

sn47.10:8.7.pli: Atha ca pana ‘vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.7.eng: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

sn47.10:8.8.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.8.eng: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

sn47.10:8.9.eng: And they understand: ‘Before and behind, it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

sn47.10:8.10.pli: Atha ca pana ‘citte cittānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.10.eng: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

sn47.10:8.11.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.11.eng: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

sn47.10:8.12.eng: And they understand: ‘Before and behind, it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

sn47.10:8.13.pli: Atha ca pana ‘dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
sn47.10:8.13.eng: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

sn47.10:8.14.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, appaṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti.
sn47.10:8.14.eng: That’s how there is undirected development.

sn47.10:9.1.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, desitā mayā paṇidhāya bhāvanā, desitā appaṇidhāya bhāvanā.
sn47.10:9.1.eng: So, Ānanda, I’ve taught you directed development and undirected development.

sn47.10:9.2.pli: Yaṃ, ānanda, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
sn47.10:9.2.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

sn47.10:9.3.pli: Etāni, ānanda, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyathānanda, mā pamādattha; mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
sn47.10:9.3.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

sn47.10:10.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn47.10:10.2.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
sn47.10:10.2.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.

sn47.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.11:1.2.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

sn47.11:1.4.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, mahāpuriso hotī”ti?
sn47.11:1.4.eng: How is a great man defined?”

sn47.11:1.5.eng: “Sāriputta, someone whose mind is free is a great man, I say.

sn47.11:1.6.eng: If their mind is not free, I say they’re not a great man.

sn47.11:2.1.eng: And how does someone have a free mind?

sn47.11:2.2.pli: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.11:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.11:2.3.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato cittaṃ virajjati, vimuccati anupādāya āsavehi.
sn47.11:2.3.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, their mind becomes dispassionate, and is freed from the defilements by not grasping.

sn47.11:2.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.11:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.11:2.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.11:2.7.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato cittaṃ virajjati, vimuccati anupādāya āsavehi.
sn47.11:2.7.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, their mind becomes dispassionate, and is freed from the defilements by not grasping.

sn47.11:2.8.eng: That’s how someone has a free mind.

sn47.11:2.9.eng: Someone whose mind is free is a great man, I say.

sn47.11:2.10.eng: If their mind is not free, I say they’re not a great man.”

sn47.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nālandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
sn47.12:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

sn47.12:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.12:1.2.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.12:1.3.eng: “Sir, I have such confidence in the Buddha that

sn47.12:1.4.pli: Na cāhu, na ca bhavissati, na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro, yadidaṃ—sambodhiyan”ti.
sn47.12:1.4.eng: I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.”

sn47.12:1.5.pli: “Uḷārā kho tyāyaṃ, sāriputta, āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, ekaṃso gahito, sīhanādo nadito:
sn47.12:1.5.eng: “That’s a grand and bold statement, Sāriputta. You’ve roared a definitive, categorical lion’s roar, saying:

sn47.12:1.6.eng: ‘I have such confidence in the Buddha that

sn47.12:1.7.pli: Na cāhu, na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro, yadidaṃ—sambodhiyan’ti.
sn47.12:1.7.eng: I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.’

sn47.12:2.1.pli: Kiṃ nu te, sāriputta, ye te ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto cetasā ceto paricca viditā:
sn47.12:2.1.eng: What about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past? Have you encompassed their minds to know that

sn47.12:2.2.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ’ iti vā, ‘evaṃdhammā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ’ iti vā, ‘evaṃpaññā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvihārino te bhagavanto ahesuṃ’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ’ iti vā”ti?
sn47.12:2.2.eng: those Buddhas had such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

sn47.12:3.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, sāriputta, ye te bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto cetasā ceto paricca viditā:
sn47.12:3.1.eng: “And what about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future? Have you encompassed their minds to know that

sn47.12:3.2.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā te bhagavanto bhavissanti’ iti vā, ‘evaṃdhammā te bhagavanto bhavissanti’ iti vā, ‘evaṃpaññā te bhagavanto bhavissanti’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvihārino te bhagavanto bhavissanti’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto bhavissanti’ iti vā”ti?
sn47.12:3.2.eng: those Buddhas will have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

sn47.12:4.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana tyāhaṃ, sāriputta, etarahi, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
sn47.12:4.1.eng: “And what about me, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha at present? Have you encompassed my mind to know that

sn47.12:4.2.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo bhagavā’ iti vā, ‘evaṃdhammo bhagavā’ iti vā, ‘evaṃpañño bhagavā’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvihārī bhagavā’ iti vā, ‘evaṃvimutto bhagavā’ iti vā”ti?
sn47.12:4.2.eng: I have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

sn47.12:5.1.pli: “Ettha ca te, sāriputta, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu cetopariyañāṇaṃ natthi.
sn47.12:5.1.eng: “In that case, Sāriputta, given that you don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, or present,

sn47.12:5.2.pli: Atha kiñcarahi tyāyaṃ, sāriputta, uḷārā āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, ekaṃso gahito, sīhanādo nadito:
sn47.12:5.2.eng: what then are you doing, making such a grand and bold statement, roaring such a definitive, categorical lion’s roar?”

sn47.12:5.4.pli: Na cāhu, na ca bhavissati, na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā’ bhiyyobhiññataro, yadidaṃ—sambodhiyan”ti?

sn47.12:6.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu cetopariyañāṇaṃ atthi,
sn47.12:6.1.eng: “Sir, though I don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, and present,

sn47.12:6.2.eng: still I understand this by inference from the teaching.

sn47.12:6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rañño paccantimaṃ nagaraṃ daḷhuddhāpaṃ daḷhapākāratoraṇaṃ ekadvāraṃ.
sn47.12:6.3.eng: Suppose there was a king’s frontier citadel with fortified embankments, ramparts, and arches, and a single gate.

sn47.12:6.4.pli: Tatrassa dovāriko paṇḍito byatto medhāvī aññātānaṃ nivāretā ñātānaṃ pavesetā.
sn47.12:6.4.eng: And it has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and intelligent. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.

sn47.12:6.5.pli: So tassa nagarassa samantā anupariyāyapathaṃ anukkamamāno na passeyya pākārasandhiṃ vā pākāravivaraṃ vā, antamaso biḷāranikkhamanamattampi.
sn47.12:6.5.eng: As he walks around the patrol path, he doesn’t see a hole or cleft in the wall, not even one big enough for a cat to slip out.

sn47.12:6.7.pli: ‘ye kho keci oḷārikā pāṇā imaṃ nagaraṃ pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā, sabbe te imināva dvārena pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā’ti.
sn47.12:6.7.eng: ‘Whatever sizable creatures enter or leave the citadel, all of them do so via this gate.’

sn47.12:6.8.pli: Evameva kho me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito:
sn47.12:6.8.eng: In the same way, I understand this by inference from the teaching:

sn47.12:6.9.pli: ‘yepi te, bhante, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya, cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā, anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhiṃsu.
sn47.12:6.9.eng: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—whether past, future, or present—give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They correctly develop the seven awakening factors. And they awaken to the supreme perfect awakening.’”

sn47.12:6.10.pli: Yepi te, bhante, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya, cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā, anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhissanti.

sn47.12:6.11.pli: Bhagavāpi, bhante, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya, cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe, catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā, anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’”ti.

sn47.12:7.2.pli: Tasmātiha tvaṃ, sāriputta, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ bhāseyyāsi bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
sn47.12:7.2.eng: So Sāriputta, you should frequently speak this exposition of the teaching to the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

sn47.12:7.3.pli: Yesampi hi, sāriputta, moghapurisānaṃ bhavissati tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, tesampimaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ sutvā yā tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā sā pahīyissatī”ti.
sn47.12:7.3.eng: Though there will be some futile people who have doubt or uncertainty regarding the Realized One, when they hear this exposition of the teaching they’ll give up that doubt or uncertainty.”

sn47.13:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn47.13:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn47.13:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto magadhesu viharati nālakagāmake ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn47.13:1.2.eng: At that time Venerable Sāriputta was staying in the Magadhan lands near the little village of Nālaka, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn47.13:1.3.pli: Cundo ca samaṇuddeso āyasmato sāriputtassa upaṭṭhāko hoti.
sn47.13:1.3.eng: And the novice Cunda was his carer.

sn47.13:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto teneva ābādhena parinibbāyi.
sn47.13:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta was fully extinguished from that sickness.

sn47.13:2.2.pli: Atha kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmato sāriputtassa pattacīvaramādāya yena sāvatthi jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.13:2.2.eng: Then Cunda took Sāriputta’s bowl and robes and set out for Sāvatthī. He went to see Venerable Ānanda at Jeta’s grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.13:2.3.eng: “Sir, Venerable Sāriputta has become fully quenched.

sn47.13:2.4.eng: This is his bowl and robe.”

sn47.13:3.1.pli: “Atthi kho idaṃ, āvuso cunda, kathāpābhataṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
sn47.13:3.1.eng: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.

sn47.13:3.2.pli: Āyāmāvuso cunda, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocessāmā”ti.
sn47.13:3.2.eng: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.”

sn47.13:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.

sn47.13:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca ānando cundo ca samaṇuddeso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.13:4.1.eng: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.13:4.3.eng: Venerable Sāriputta has become fully quenched.

sn47.13:4.4.eng: This is his bowl and robe.

sn47.13:4.5.pli: Api ca me, bhante, madhurakajāto viya kāyo, disāpi me na pakkhāyanti, dhammāpi maṃ nappaṭibhanti ‘āyasmā sāriputto parinibbuto’ti sutvā”.
sn47.13:4.5.eng: Since I heard this, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, and the teachings don’t spring to mind.”

sn47.13:5.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho te, ānanda, sāriputto sīlakkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto, samādhikkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto, paññākkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto, vimuttikkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto, vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto”ti?
sn47.13:5.1.eng: “Well, Ānanda, when Sāriputta was fully quenched, did he take away your entire spectrum of ethical conduct, of immersion, of wisdom, of freedom, or of the knowledge and vision of freedom?”

sn47.13:5.2.pli: “Na ca kho me, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto sīlakkhandhaṃ vā ādāya parinibbuto, samādhikkhandhaṃ vā …pe…

sn47.13:5.6.pli: Api ca me, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto ovādako ahosi otiṇṇo viññāpako sandassako samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako, akilāsu dhammadesanāya, anuggāhako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
sn47.13:5.6.eng: But Venerable Sāriputta was my adviser and counselor. He educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired me. He never tired of teaching the Dhamma, and he supported his spiritual companions.

sn47.13:5.7.pli: Taṃ mayaṃ āyasmato sāriputtassa dhammojaṃ dhammabhogaṃ dhammānuggahaṃ anussarāmā”ti.
sn47.13:5.7.eng: I remember the nectar of the teaching, the riches of the teaching, the support of the teaching given by Venerable Sāriputta.”

sn47.13:6.1.eng: “Ānanda, did I not prepare for this when I explained that

sn47.13:6.2.eng: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

sn47.13:6.3.pli: Taṃ kutettha, ānanda, labbhā. Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjīti—
sn47.13:6.3.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

sn47.13:6.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato yo mahantataro khandho so palujjeyya;
sn47.13:6.5.eng: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood, and the largest branch broke off.

sn47.13:6.6.pli: evameva kho ānanda, mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāriputto parinibbuto.
sn47.13:6.6.eng: In the same way, in the great Saṅgha that stands with heartwood, Sāriputta has become fully quenched.

sn47.13:6.7.pli: Taṃ kutettha, ānanda, labbhā. Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjī’ti—
sn47.13:6.7.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

sn47.13:6.9.pli: Tasmātihānanda, attadīpā viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
sn47.13:6.9.eng: So Ānanda, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.13:7.1.pli: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
sn47.13:7.1.eng: And how does a mendicant do this?

sn47.13:7.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.13:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.13:7.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.13:7.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.13:7.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.13:7.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
sn47.13:7.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.13:7.7.pli: Ye hi keci, ānanda, etarahi vā mamaccaye vā attadīpā viharissanti attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā; tamatagge mete, ānanda, bhikkhū bhavissanti ye keci sikkhākāmā”ti.
sn47.13:7.7.eng: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”

sn47.14:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vajjīsu viharati ukkacelāyaṃ gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aciraparinibbutesu sāriputtamoggallānesu.
sn47.14:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. It was not long after Sāriputta and Moggallāna had become fully quenched.

sn47.14:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto ajjhokāse nisinno hoti.
sn47.14:1.2.eng: Now, at that time the Buddha was sitting in the open, surrounded by the Saṅgha of mendicants.

sn47.14:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn47.14:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were silent. He addressed them:

sn47.14:2.2.pli: “api myāyaṃ, bhikkhave, parisā suññā viya khāyati parinibbutesu sāriputtamoggallānesu.
sn47.14:2.2.eng: “Mendicants, this assembly seems empty to me now that Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become fully quenched.

sn47.14:2.3.pli: Asuññā me, bhikkhave, parisā hoti, anapekkhā tassaṃ disāyaṃ hoti, yassaṃ disāyaṃ sāriputtamoggallānā viharanti.
sn47.14:2.3.eng: When Sāriputta and Moggallāna were alive, my assembly was never empty; I had no concern for any region where they stayed.

sn47.14:2.4.pli: Ye hi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamaṃyeva sāvakayugaṃ ahosi—
sn47.14:2.4.eng: The Buddhas of the past or the future have pairs of chief disciples who are no better than

sn47.14:2.5.eng: Sāriputta and Moggallāna were to me.

sn47.14:2.6.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamaṃyeva sāvakayugaṃ bhavissati—seyyathāpi mayhaṃ sāriputtamoggallānā.

sn47.14:2.7.pli: Acchariyaṃ, bhikkhave, sāvakānaṃ, abbhutaṃ, bhikkhave, sāvakānaṃ.
sn47.14:2.7.eng: It’s an incredible and amazing quality of such disciples

sn47.14:2.8.pli: Satthu ca nāma sāsanakarā bhavissanti ovādappaṭikarā, catunnañca parisānaṃ piyā bhavissanti manāpā garubhāvanīyā ca.
sn47.14:2.8.eng: that they fulfill the Teacher’s instructions and follow his advice. And they’re liked and approved, respected and admired by the four assemblies.

sn47.14:2.9.pli: Acchariyaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa, abbhutaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa.
sn47.14:2.9.eng: And it’s an incredible and amazing quality of the Realized One

sn47.14:2.10.pli: Evarūpepi nāma sāvakayuge parinibbute natthi tathāgatassa soko vā paridevo vā.
sn47.14:2.10.eng: that when such a pair of disciples becomes fully quenched he does not sorrow or lament.

sn47.14:2.11.pli: Taṃ kutettha, bhikkhave, labbhā. Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjīti—
sn47.14:2.11.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

sn47.14:2.13.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato ye mahantatarā khandhā te palujjeyyuṃ;
sn47.14:2.13.eng: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood, and the largest branches broke off.

sn47.14:2.14.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāriputtamoggallānā parinibbutā.
sn47.14:2.14.eng: In the same way, in the great Saṅgha that stands with heartwood, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have become fully quenched.

sn47.14:2.15.pli: Taṃ kutettha, bhikkhave, labbhā. Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjīti—
sn47.14:2.15.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

sn47.14:2.17.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, attadīpā viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
sn47.14:2.17.eng: So mendicants, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.14:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
sn47.14:3.1.eng: And how does a mendicant do this?

sn47.14:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.14:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.14:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.14:3.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.14:3.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.14:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
sn47.14:3.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.14:3.7.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, etarahi vā mamaccaye vā attadīpā viharissanti attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā; tamatagge mete, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhavissanti ye keci sikkhākāmā”ti.
sn47.14:3.7.eng: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”

sn47.15:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bāhiyo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā bāhiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.15:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Bāhiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.15:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.15:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn47.15:1.4.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, bāhiya, ādimeva visodhehi kusalesu dhammesu.
sn47.15:1.4.eng: “Well then, Bāhiya, you should purify the starting point of skillful qualities.

sn47.15:1.5.eng: What is the starting point of skillful qualities?

sn47.15:1.6.eng: Well purified ethics and correct view.

sn47.15:1.7.pli: Yato ca kho te, bāhiya, sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ bhavissati, diṭṭhi ca ujukā, tato tvaṃ, bāhiya, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāveyyāsi.
sn47.15:1.7.eng: When your ethics are well purified and your view is correct, you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn47.15:2.2.pli: Idha tvaṃ, bāhiya, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.15:2.2.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.15:2.3.eng: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.15:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.15:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.15:2.6.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bāhiya, sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṃ bhāvessasi, tato tuyhaṃ, bāhiya, yā ratti vā divaso vā āgamissati, vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu, no parihānī”ti.
sn47.15:2.6.eng: When you develop these four kinds of mindfulness meditation, depending on and grounded on ethics, you can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.”

sn47.15:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bāhiyo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn47.15:3.1.eng: And then Venerable Bāhiya approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn47.15:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bāhiyo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn47.15:3.2.eng: Then Bāhiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn47.15:3.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn47.15:3.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn47.15:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā bāhiyo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn47.15:3.4.eng: And Venerable Bāhiya became one of the perfected.
